data.title: Share word matching between hover and inline values
Wording tweak to openFolderInNewWindow setting
data.body:
Testing #18609

```
// Controls if folders should open in a new window or the last active window.
```

Suggest to tweak to 
```
// Controls if folders should open in a new window or _replace_ the last active window.
```

data.title: Get rid of updateEnablement in debugActions
Markdown: editing our 1.9 release notes flickers more than before
data.body: I notice that when I edit our 1.9 release notes, the markdown preview seems to jump up and down all the time there is a change. Compared to 1.8 stable, this seemed to not happen.

data.title: Feature Request [Editor] [Preview] with different Themes
data.body:
Feature Request

It would be nice to have the possibility to select two different themes for the Editor and the Preview.
Even better it would be if you can set this on a per Language Base.

I d' like to use my Editor always set to dark theme but the preview i'd like to have in light mode.
Espacially for Markdown

data.title: introduce 'default' for menu bar visibility
Allow users to do copy paste in the integrated terminal using ctrl+c, ctrl+v
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
All versions
- OS Version:
Ubuntu

Within terminal if you need to copy text, currently we need to use `ctrl+insert` & for pasting `shift+insert`

However, this is a strange way to do this especially in an editor.

Intellij allows you to copy & paste text within terminal using `ctrl+c` & `ctrl+v`

If text is selected within terminal using mouse, `ctrl+c` would trigger copy. If no text is selected & `ctrl+c` is pressed, this would lead to usual cancellation of the running program, i.e exactly the way it is behaving now.

`ctrl+v` should paste the text bindly from clipboard

So, `ctrl+c` should selection sensitive `copy/cancel` & `ctrl+v` is blind paste

data.title: IntelliSense not working when using absolute import paths
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. As an example I use my `actionTypes.js` which has redux action type constants like this:
```javascript
export const START_THING = 'START_THING';
export const START_THING_DONE = 'START_THING_DONE';
```
2. Then when I import them with relative path like this the IntelliSense is working like so:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12229968/22282298/2b5dd844-e2e4-11e6-9155-c7cff4b27847.png)
3. But if I use absolute import (which is always better choice than relative) then IntelliSense does not pick up constants from `actionTypes.js` file like so:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12229968/22282354/775c87d6-e2e4-11e6-97ee-77b82e4278bd.png)

data.title: Markdown Preview: Links to markdown files in the workspace should also open in the preview

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: VSCode 1.9 added support for workspace links in the markdown preview. These currently open an editor window. Instead, I think clicking a link to a file in the workspace in the markdown preview should open that file in a new markdown preview.

data.body:

data.title: Incorrect Comment Highlighting for "ini".
data.body:
It seems github has the same highlight error. The ";" character doesn't indicate a comment in the following context:

```ini
; comment
[Something]
VAR=%VAR%;addition
;        ^~~~~~ not a comment
```

data.title: typescript formater randomly adds and removes spaces
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a typescript file with something that has a callback function (not a lambda), example:
```
$('.onoffswitch').click(function () {
	//....
});
```
2. Watch tslint complain about `Spaces before function parens are disallowed (space-before-function-paren)`.

3. Save the file, watch the space between the function and parens disappear, edit something and save the file again and watch it randomly get back.

data.title: Debug console using integrated terminal should not run under the user defined shell
data.body:
Testing #19039

The command should be launched using `bash -c` or `cmd /c` (I think), which will run it under a consistent shell and exit upon completion. You can also now tell the terminal to wait on exit using the `waitOnExit` arg on `TerminalInstance`.

Starting debug under git bash:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/22276962/8ef11ec0-e26c-11e6-8bf2-e56a5dda55d8.png)

Support for reusing terminals is also on the way which could be useful.

data.title: Cannot Expand Thrown Errors in Node Debug Console
data.body:
Testing #15796

1. Start debugging a node2 program
1. Run `throw {x: 2}` in the debug console

**Expected**
When running `console.error({x: 2})`, an expandable object is printed

**Actual**
Only prints the error text in this case

![screen shot 2017-01-24 at 7 13 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/22276525/2711771c-e269-11e6-99a9-31787968a8c6.png)

data.title: Node debug Print of Function Object generates errors for `arguments` and `caller`
data.body:
Testing #15901


1. start debugging any node program
1. Print out a function object: `() => 0`


**Error**
![screen shot 2017-01-24 at 7 03 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/22276366/ebd39082-e267-11e6-8ddf-dabba7e9a685.png)

`arguments` and `callee` both generate errors when the parent function is expanded

data.title: Using "window.newWindowDimensions":"inherit"  with FullScreen Editor on OSX Does not Open FullScreen on Second Monitor
data.body:
Test item #18632

- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev 1.9.0 (Commit unknown, Date unknown)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

On OSX machine with two displays connected. I use a laptop with a large monitor connected. The laptop is set the primary monitor

1. Set `"window.newWindowDimensions":"inherit"`
1. Have vscode window on the smaller screen (laptop)
1. Make window fullscreen.
1. Create New window.

**Expected**
New window is created fullscreen on the laptop monitor

**Actual**
The new window is created in the middle of the screen on the secondary monitor

data.title: JS -> TS sourcemaps aren't working for me when debugging tests
data.body:
I created the following launch.json to try get debugging working on [xterm.js](https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js)' tests:

```js
{
  // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
  // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
  // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Mocha Tests",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha",
      "windows": {
        "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha.cmd"
      },
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "--colors",
        "--recursive",
        "${workspaceRoot}/lib"
      ],
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart"
    }
  ]
}
```

While debugging works I cannot put breakpoints on the source TS files, I have to put them on the JS files at which point the TS files are hit. Breakpoints on the TS files look like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/22276070/172d5346-e266-11e6-8277-c4dfa7706359.png)

Which tells me there could be a sourcemap problem but I don't know how to fix it  This is how the sourcemaps link to the TS file:

```
{"version":3,"sources":["../src/Viewport.ts"]
```

The project is laid out like this:

`src/Viewport.ts`
`src/Viewport.test.ts`

Which compiles to:

`lib/Viewport.js`
`lib/Viewport.test.js`

data.title: Change TypeScript Configuration Flow For workspacesTrustedToSpecifyExecutables
data.body:
Part of #19113

This change removes the message that appears when you load a unconfigured TS workspace with a local version of typescript since #19113 breaks that flow.

The new flow makes the following changes:

* Use the bundled version of TS by default
* Always show the TS version in the status bar, even if we are using the bundled version
* When the user clicks on the status bar version, one of three things can happen:
    * If there is a local version of ts installed but the workspace is not configured, show a message about selecting the workspace or bundled version of TS.
    * If the no local version of ts is installed or the user has opted to use the bundled version explicitly, show a message about using the bundled version along with a blurb about the `typescript.tsdk` setting.
    * If the user as set `typescript.tsdk`, show a message about using the workspace version along with a blurb about the `typescript.tsdk` setting.

data.title: Can't kill the vscode build task
data.body:
- Start the build task for the vscode repo
- Run "Terminate running task"
- See error `"The tasks are executed in the intergrated terminal. Use the terminal to manage the tasks."`

I assume that's not supposed to show up here, since the task is not running in the terminal. Now there's no way to stop the task.
